articles.headline: Battle Is Set as Verizon Adds iPhone
articles.snippet: The highly anticipated move marks the end of a five-year agreement of exclusivity between Apple and AT&T.
articles.abstract: The highly anticipated move marks the end of a five-year agreement of exclusivity between Apple and AT&T.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ending months of speculation, Verizon announced on Tuesday that it would begin selling Apple’s iPhone 4 early next month.

articles.headline: Hot Social Networking Site Cools as Facebook Grows
articles.snippet: No longer trying to compete with Facebook, MySpace recently revamped its site to give users more ways to consume music, videos and celebrity gossip.
articles.abstract: No longer trying to compete with Facebook, MySpace recently revamped its site to give users more ways to consume music, videos and celebrity gossip.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Facebook was negotiating a half-billion-dollar investment from Goldman Sachs recently, MySpace, once the dominant Web site for social networking, was preparing to fire nearly half its staff.

articles.headline: Foreigners Shun Europe’s Bonds, and Debt Piles Up
articles.snippet: Greece, Ireland and Portugal all tapped domestic banks after they’d been shut out of international bond markets.
articles.abstract: Greece, Ireland and Portugal all tapped domestic banks after they’d been shut out of international bond markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS  Greece. Ireland. And now, it seems, Portugal.

articles.headline: Rising Chinese Inflation to Show Up in U.S. Imports
articles.snippet: The 5.1 percent rise in Chinese consumer prices in November understated the actual inflation rate, which economists said might be twice as high.
articles.abstract: The 5.1 percent rise in Chinese consumer prices in November understated the actual inflation rate, which economists said might be twice as high.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  When garment buyers from New York show up next month at China’s annual trade shows to bargain over next autumn’s fashions, many will face sticker shock.

articles.headline: Auto Show Outsiders Seek Rebirth
articles.snippet: Automakers like Saab and Volvo, which were sold off by parents like General Motors and Ford, are determined to get positive attention in Detroit.
articles.abstract: Automakers like Saab and Volvo, which were sold off by parents like General Motors and Ford, are determined to get positive attention in Detroit.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  In early 2010, General Motors kicked its Saab brand to the curb as part of its postbankruptcy reorganization.

articles.headline: The Real Problem With China
articles.snippet: For the United States, the main trouble with China’s economy is probably intellectual property theft, followed by protectionist barriers to trade.
articles.abstract: For the United States, the main trouble with China’s economy is probably intellectual property theft, followed by protectionist barriers to trade.

articles.headline: Legal Strategy Could Hinge on Mental Assessment
articles.snippet: Because of changes made after John Hinckley was acquitted for trying to kill President Reagan, the lawyers for Jared L. Loughner will find it difficult to argue the insanity defense.
articles.abstract: Because of changes made after John Hinckley was acquitted for trying to kill President Reagan, the lawyers for Jared L. Loughner will find it difficult to argue the insanity defense.
articles.lead_paragraph: The disturbing photograph of Jared L. Loughner that was released after his arrest, as well as the writings and statements attributed to him, seemed to point to a man with a mental disorder.

articles.headline: Oil Pipeline in Alaska Has Plan to Restart
articles.snippet: The Trans Alaska Pipeline System has temporarily restarted the flow of oil, though repairs were not complete on a leak that forced a shutdown on Saturday.
articles.abstract: The Trans Alaska Pipeline System has temporarily restarted the flow of oil, though repairs were not complete on a leak that forced a shutdown on Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Worried about the effect of freezing temperatures, the operator of the Trans Alaska Pipeline System said Wednesday that it had temporarily restarted the flow of oil through its 800-mile network, even though repairs had not yet been completed on the leak that forced the shutdown of the system on Saturday.

articles.headline: Police Say They Visited Tucson Suspect’s Home Even Before Rampage
articles.snippet: The police said they were reviewing the details of their calls to the home of Jared L. Loughner, who was described by a friend as having embraced nihilism.
articles.abstract: The police said they were reviewing the details of their calls to the home of Jared L. Loughner, who was described by a friend as having embraced nihilism.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Jo Becker, Kirk Johnson and Serge F. Kovaleski.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker, Kirk Johnson and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Bit by Bit, a Mexican Police Force Is Eradicated
articles.snippet: The disappearance of a police chief is a sign of how the war with organized crime is battering Mexico’s small towns.
articles.abstract: The disappearance of a police chief is a sign of how the war with organized crime is battering Mexico’s small towns.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUADALUPE DISTRITO BRAVOS, Mexico — Her uncle, the mayor who gave her the job nobody else wanted, warned her to keep a low profile, to not make too much of being the last remaining police officer in a town where the rest of the force had quit or been killed.

articles.headline: Resignations Deepen Crisis for Lebanon
articles.snippet: Hezbollah cabinet ministers and their allies resigned, toppling a unity government that had brought a period of relative calm to the troubled nation.
articles.abstract: Hezbollah cabinet ministers and their allies resigned, toppling a unity government that had brought a period of relative calm to the troubled nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollah and its political allies withdrew from Lebanon’s cabinet on Wednesday, toppling a national unity government that had brought a measure of calm to the troubled Middle Eastern country since 2009 and deepening an emerging crisis over a United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the assassination of a former prime minister.

articles.headline: Bond Sale a Success in Portugal
articles.snippet: Portuguese officials said the successful auction vindicated their plan to finance debt through the markets rather than ask for help from Europe’s rescue fund.
articles.abstract: Portuguese officials said the successful auction vindicated their plan to finance debt through the markets rather than ask for help from Europe’s rescue fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: Portugal won some breathing room Wednesday with a better-than-expected bond auction that fueled a rise in global stock markets and led the government to reaffirm its stance against accepting a bailout.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: Geithner Urges New Start for U.S.-China Relations
articles.snippet: As the United States prepares for a visit from China’s president, the Treasury secretary suggested a fresh start in relations.
articles.abstract: As the United States prepares for a visit from China’s president, the Treasury secretary suggested a fresh start in relations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner on Wednesday suggested a fresh start in relations between the United States and China, aimed at mutually beneficial economic growth.
